question: Fifteen men on a dead man's chest. Yo ho ho, and a *bottle* of rum. Drink and the devil had done for the rest. Yo ho ho, and a *bottle* of rum. Ha-ha-ha-ha-ha!
answer: Sorry, mate. Mind if we make a little side trip? I didn't think so.

question: Not *quite* according to plan.
answer: Complications arose, ensued, were overcome.

question: You got what you went in for, then?
answer: Mm-hmm!

question: Those won't be necessary. The East India Trading Company has need of your services. We wish for you to act as our agent in a business transaction with our mutual friend
answer: More acquaintance than friend. How do you know him?

question: We've had dealings in the past. And we've each left our mark... on the other.
answer: What mark did he leave on you?

question: By your efforts Jack Sparrow was set free. I would like you to go to him, and recover a certain property in his possession.
answer: Recover. At the point of a sword?

question: *Bargain*! Letters of Marque. You will offer what amounts to a full pardon. Jack will be free, a privateer in the employ of England.
answer: Somehow I doubt Jack will consider employment the same as being free.

question: Freedom. Jack Sparrow is a dying breed. The world is shrinking, the blank pages of the map filled in. Jack must find his place in the new world or perish. Not unlike you, Mister Turner. You and your fiance face the hangman's noose.
answer: So you get both Jack *and* the Black Pearl.

question: The Black Pearl?
answer: The property you want that he possesses.

question: Why is the rum always gone? Oh! *That's* why. As you were, gents. Ah! Bootstrap. Bill Turner. Is this a dream? I thought not. If it were, there'd be rum. I had some help retrieving the Pearl, by the way. Your son. And to what do I owe the pleasure of your carbuncle? Who? Ah. So it's you, then. He shanghaied you into service, eh? It's funny what a man will do to forestall his final judgment - Technic - Yes, but the Flying Dutchman already *has* a captain, so there's re - Any idea when Jones might release said terrible beastie? On deck all hands! Make fast the bunt gasket! On deck! Scurry! ?Scurry-on/?Marty, I want movement! *I want movement!*
answer: Lift the skin up!

question: All on deck! Run! And keep running! Run as if the devil himself and itself is upon us!
answer: Do we have a heading?

question: Ah! Ooh! Run! Land. Oh! Euh!
answer: Which port?

question: Didn't say port. I said land. Any land. Agh!
answer: Jack's hat! Bring 'er about!

question: No no! Leave it! Run!
answer: Back to your stations! The lot o' ya! Jack?

question: Shhh!
answer: For the love of mother and child, Jack, what's coming after us?

question: Jack's Compass. What does Beckett want with that?
answer: Does it matter? I'm to find Jack and convince him to return to Port Royal. In exchange the charges against us will be dropped. Is that lack of faith in Jack, or in me?

question: I have faith in you. Both of you. Where will you find him?
answer: Tortuga. I'll start there, and I won't stop searching 'til I find him. And then I intend to return here, to marry you.

question: Properly?
answer: Eagerly, if you'll still have me.

question: If it weren't for these bars I'd have you already. I'll wait for you.
answer: Keep a weather eye on the horizon.

question: What's wrong? The beach is right there. What? Jack! Jack Sparrow! Marty! Cotton! Anybody?
answer: Awk!

question: Ah! A familiar face!
answer: Rawk! Don't eat me!

question: I'm not gonna eat you.
answer: Don't eat me! No! Don't eat me! Akkk!

question: No doubt you've discovered that loyalty is no longer the currency of the realm, as your father believes.
answer: Then what is?

question: I'm afraid that *currency* is the currency of the realm.
answer: I expect then that we can come to some sort of understanding. I'm here to negotiate.

question: I'm listening. I'm listening *intently*.
answer: These Letters of Marque, they are signed by the King?

question: Yes, and they're not valid until they bear my signature and my seal.
answer: Or else I would not still be here. You sent Will to get you the Compass owned by Jack Sparrow. It will do you no good.

question: Do explain.
answer: I have been to Isla de Muerta, I have seen the treasure myself. There is something you need to know.

question: Ah, I see. *You* think the Compass leads only to the Isla de Muerta, and so you hope to *save* me from an evil fate. But you mustn't worry. I care not for cursed Aztec gold. My desires are not so provincial. There's more than one chest of value in these waters. So perhaps you may wish to enhance your offer.
answer: Consider into your calculations that you robbed me of my wedding night.

question: So I did. A marriage interrupted. Or fate intervenes. You make great efforts to ensure Jack Sparrow's freedom.
answer: These aren't going to Jack.

question: Well I say it was divine providence what escaped us from jail.
answer: And I say... it was me bein' *clever*. Ain't that right, poochie?
It ain't stealin'. It's *salvagin'*! And since when did you care?

question: Since we're not immortal no more. We gotta take care of our immortal souls.
answer: You know you can't read.

question: It's the Bible. You get credit for trying.
answer: Pretendin' to read the Bible's a *lie*! *That's* a mark against ya! Look! There it is!

question: What's got into *'im*?
answer: Must've seen a catfish. Heh-heh-heh-heh-heh-heh.

question: Come on! Ha-ha-ha-ha-ha-ha. Ha-ha-ha-ha... It's ours for the taking!
answer: Tide's comin', that should help. Well, salvagin' is saving, in a manner of speaking.

question: There's the truth of *it*! ###
answer: Suppose we be'er... save it as soon as we can. What with our souls in such a vulnerable state, and all.

question: Why would he do this to us? If Jack is their chief.
answer: Aye, the Pelegostos made Jack their chief. But he only remains chief as long as he *acts* like a chief.

question: So he had no choice. He's a captive then as much as the rest of us.
answer: Worse... as it turns out. See, the Pelegostos believe that Jack is a *god* in human form, and they intend to do him the honor of releasing him from his fleshy prison. ?Argh! They'll roast him and eat him.

question: Where's the rest of the crew?
answer: These cages we're in... weren't built 'til *after* we got here. The feast is about to begin. Jack's life will end... when the drums stop.

question: throne
answer: ?No/?Oup! No no! ?Oy!/?Wait! No no! More wood! Big fire! *Big* fire! I am chief! Want big fire! Come on! ?Oy!/?Boy! Maboogie snickel-snickel. Tout de suite! Come on! More wood!

question: Jack
answer: Oh bugger. Little seasoning. Eh? Well done.

question: ?Pull-loose/?Unloose the mooring lines! The mooring lines!
answer: ?Thief/?Thing! Little hairy ?thief/?thing! Give it back! Don't bite it!

question: ?Unloose the mooring lines!
answer: He's got me eye! He won't give it back!

question: *Cast off those lines!*
answer: Good doggie! ?Doggie. *Alas*, my children! This is the day you shall always remember as the day that you almost - ...Captain Jack... Sparrow.

question: Let's put some distance between us and this island, and head out to open sea.
answer: Yes to the first, yes to the second, but only insofar as we keep to the shallows as much as possible.

question: Uh, that seems a bit contradictory, Captain.
answer: I have every faith in your reconciliatory navigational skills, Master Gibbs, now where is that monkey? I want to shoot *something*.

question: I have every faith in your reconciliatory navigational skills, Master Gibbs, now where is that monkey? I want to shoot *something*.
answer: Jack.

question: Ah.
answer: Elizabeth is in danger.

question: Have you considered keeping a more watchful eye on 'er? Maybe just lock her up somewhere.
answer: She *is* locked up, in a prison, bound to hang for helping *you*!

question: There comes a time when one must take responsibility for one's mistakes.
answer: I need that Compass of yours, Jack. I must trade it for her freedom.

question: Mister Gibbs!
answer: Cap'n.

question: We have a need to travel upriver.
answer: By need, d'you mean a... trifling need, ?uh/?a... fleeting, as in say in a passing fancy?

question: No, a... resolute and unyielding need.
answer: What we need to do is make sail for Port Royal with all haste.

question: William... I shall trade you the Compass, if you will help me... to find *this*.
answer: You want me to find this?

question: No. *You* want you to find this. Because the finding this finds you incapacitorially finding and/or locating and your discovering the detecting of a way to save your ?dolly/?dotty belle ol'... what's-her-face. Savvy?
answer: This... is going to save Elizabeth?

question: How much do you know about Davy Jones?
answer: Not much.

question: Why is Jack afraid of the open ocean?
answer: Well, if you believe such things, there's a beast does the bidding of Davy Jones. A fearsome creature with giant tentacles that suction your face clean off. And drag an entire ship past the crushing darkness. The Kraken! They say the stench of its breath is like - ooh! Imagine

question: And the key will spare him that?
answer: Now that's the very question Jack wants answered. Bad enough even to go visit... *Her*.

question: Her?
answer: Aye.

question: Aye.
answer: No worries, mates. Tia Dalma and I go way back. Thick as thieves. Nigh inseparable we are. Were. Have been. Before.

question: I'll watch your back.
answer: It's me front I'm worried about. Mind the boat.

question: You want to know *me*.
answer: There'll be no knowing here. We've come for help and we're not leaving without it. I thought *I* knew you.

question: Not so well as I had hoped. Come.
answer: Come.

question: What... service... may I do you? Hmmm? You know I demand payment.
answer: I brought payment. Look! An undead monkey! Top that!

question: The payment is fair.
answer: We're looking for this. And what it goes to.

question: The Compass you bartered from me. It cannot lead you to dis?
answer: Maybe. Why?

question: My eyesight's as good as ever, just so you know.
answer: I am justMy little ###, where are you? ### Davy Jones cannot make port. Cannot step on land but once every ten years. Land is where you are safe, Jack Sparrow. And so you will carry land wid you...

question: Dirt. This is a jar of dirt.
answer: Yes?

question: Is the... jar of dirt going to help?
answer: If you don' want it, give it back.

question: No.
answer: Den it helps.

question: So what's your plan, then?
answer: I row over, search the ship until I find your bloody key.

question: And if there are crewmen?
answer: I cut down anyone in my path.

question: I like it. Simple, easy to remember.
answer: Your chariot awaits you, sire! Ha, ha-ha-ha, ha-ha!

question: Hey! If you *do* happen to get captured, just say Jack Sparrow sent you to settle his debt! Might save your life!
answer: Bon voyage! Ha-ha-ha!

question: Do you fear death? Do you fear that dark abyss? All your deeds laid bare. All your sins punished. I can offer you... an escape-uh. Do you not fear death? To the depths. Life is cruel. Why should the afterlife be any *different*? I offer you a choice. Join my crew, and postpone the judgment. One hundred years before the mast. Will ye serve? ?Grand. *You* are neither dead nor dying. What is your purpose here?
answer: Jack Sparrow sent me to settle his debt.

question: What is your purpose here?
answer: Jack Sparrow. He sent me to settle his debt.

question: Huh! Did he, now? I'm sorely tempted to accept that offer.
answer: Oh.

question: You have a debt to pay. You've been captain of the Black Pearl for thirteen years. *That* was our agreement.
answer: Technically, I was only captain for two years, then I was viciously mutinied upon.

question: Then you were a poor captain, but a *captain* nonetheless! Have you not introduced yourself all these years as *Captain* Jack Sparrow?
answer: You have my payment. One soul to serve on your ship is already over there.

question: One soul is not equal to another.
answer: Aha! So we've established my proposal is sound in principle, now we're just haggling over price.

question: Price? Pttt!
answer: Just how many souls do you think my soul is worth?

question: One hundred souls, three days-uh.
answer: You're a diamond, mate. Send me back the boy, I'll get started right off.

question: I keep the boy. A good-faith payment. That leaves you only ninety-nine more to go. Ha ha! Ha ha! Ha ha!
answer: Have you not met Will Turner? He's noble, heroic, *terrific* soprano. Worth at least four... maybe three and a half. And did I happen to mention... he's in love. With a girl. Due to be married. Betrothed. Dividing him from her and her from him... would only be half as cruel as actually allowing them be joined in holy matrimony. Aye?

question: I keep the boy. Ninety-nine souls-uh. But I wonder, Sparrow, can you live with this? Can you condemn an innocent man - a friend-uh - to a lifetime of servitude, in your name while you roam free?
answer: Yep! I'm good with it. Should we seal it in blood? I mean... mm-mm - ink? Uh!

question: Three days. Three days.
answer: Oh, Mr. Gibbs.

question: Oh, Mr. Gibbs.
answer: Aye.

question: Uh, I feel sullied and unusual.
answer: And how do you intend to harvest these ninety-nine souls in three days?

question: Fortunately, he was mum as the condition in which these souls need be.
answer: Ah... Tortuga!

question: And what makes you think you're worthy to crew the Black Pearl? You'll do. Make your mark. Next! Perfect! Next! It's the crow's nest for you.
answer: I know what I want.

question: Next! Sooner than you think. Sign the roster.
answer: How we going?

question: Including those four? That gives us - four! And what's *your* story?
answer: My story... it's exactly the same as your story, just one chapter behind. I chased a man across the Seven Seas. The pursuit cost me my crew, my commission, and my life.

question: Commodore?
answer: No, not anymore, weren't you *listening*? I nearly had you all, off Tripoli. I would have, if not for the... hurricane.

question: Lord. You didn't try to sail through it?
answer: So do I make your crew, or not? You haven't said where you're going. Somewhere *nice*! So am I *worthy* to serve under Captain Jack Sparrow? Or should I just kill you now?

question: Captain Sparrow!
answer: Come to join me crew, lad? Welcome aboard.

question: I'm here to find the man I love.
answer: I'm deeply flattered, son, but my first and only love is the sea.

question: Meaning William Turner, Captain Sparrow.
answer: Elizabeth. Hide the rum. You know, these clothes do not flatter you at all. It should be a dress or nothing. I happen to have no dress in my cabin.

question: Jack. I know Will came to find you. Where is he?
answer: Darling, I am truly unhappy to have to tell you this but... through an unfortunate and *entirely* unforeseeable series of circumstances that have nothing whatsoever to do with me, poor William has been press-ganged into Davy Jones' crew.

question: You *smell* funny.
answer: Jack. All I want is to find Will.

question: Are you certain? Is that what you really want most?
answer: 'Course.

question: Because I would think, you'd want to find a way to *save* Will the most.
answer: And you have a way of doing that?

question: True enough. This Compass does not point north.
answer: Where does it point?

question: It points to the thing you want most in this world.
answer: Oh Jack! Are you telling the truth?

question: Every word, love. And what you want most in this world is to find the chest of Davy Jones, is it not?
answer: To save Will?

question: By finding the chest of Davy Jones. Mister Gibbs!
answer: Cap'n.

question: We have our heading.
answer: Finally! Cast off those lines, weigh anchor, and prow that canvas!

question: I understand. It's a game of deception. Your bet includes all the dice, not just your own. What are they wagering? So any crewman can be challenged? I challenge Davy Jones.
answer: I accept ?that-uh. The stakes?

question: My soul. An eternity of servitude.
answer: Against?

question: I want this.
answer: How do you know of the key?

question: That's not part of the game, is it? You can still walk away.
answer: What's this?

question: No! Don't do this.
answer: Four fours.

question: Four fives.
answer: Seven fives-uh.

question: Eight fives.
answer: Huh huh huh. Welcome to the crew, liar. And be called a liar myself for my trouble? Bootstrap Bill, you're a liar and you will spend an eternity on this ship! Master Turner, feel free to go ashore... the very next time we make port!

question: Agh.
answer: Will was working for Beckett, and never said a word.

question: Agh.
answer: Beckett wants the Compass. Only one reason for that.

question: Might I inquire how as to how you came by these?
answer: Persuasion.

question: Friendly?
answer: Decidedly not.

question: Will strikes a deal for these and upholds it with honor. Yet you're the one standing here with the prize. Full pardon, commission as a privateer on behalf of England and the East India Trading Company. As if I could be bought for such a low price.
answer: Jack, the Letters, give them back.

question: No. Persuade me.
answer: You do know Will taught me how handle a sword.

question: It's a curious thing. There was a time when I would've given anything for you to look like that while thinking about me.
answer: I don't know what you mean.

question: Oh, I think you do.
answer: Oh, don't be absurd. I trust him, that's all.

question: Strange thing to come upon a longboat so far out in open waters.
answer: Just put as many leagues behind us as you can. As fast as you can.

question: And what are we running from?
answer: That dress. Where did you get it?

question: It was found aboard the ship. The crew it thought it was a spirit bringing some omen of ill fate.
answer: That's foolish.

question: My tremendous intuitive sense of the female creature informs me that you are troubled.
answer: I just thought I'd be married by now. I'm so ready to be married.

question: You know... Lizzy... I *am*... captain of a ship. And *being* captain of a ship, I could in fact perform a... marriage. Right here. Right on this deck. Right... *now*!
answer: No, thank you.

question: Why not? We *are* very much alike, you and I. I and you. Us.
answer: Oh. Except for a sense of honor, and decency and-and a moral center. And personal hygiene.

question: Trifles. You *will* come over to my side, I know it.
answer: You seem very certain.

question: One word love
answer: Why doesn't your Compass work?

question: Uh my Compass works fine.
answer: Because you and I *are* alike, and there will come a moment when you have a chance to show it. To do the right thing.

question: I *love* those moments. I like to wave at them as they pass by.
answer: You'll have the chance to do something... something courageous. And when you do, you'll discover something

question: All evidence to the contrary.
answer: I have faith in you. Want to know why?

question: Do tell, dearie.
answer: Curiosity. You're going to want it. A chance to be admired. And gain the rewards that follow. You won't be able to resist. You're going to want to know... what it tastes like.

question: I *do* want to know what it tastes like.
answer: But - seeing as you're a good man I know you will *never* put me in a position that would compromise my honor. I'm proud of you, Jack.

question: You're pullin' too fast.
answer: You're pulling too slow. We don't want the Kraken to catch us.

question: I'm savin' me strength for when it comes. And I don't think it's Krack-en, anyways. I always heard it said Kray-kin.
answer: What, with a long A?

question: Aye.
answer: No-no-no-no-no-no-no. Krock-en's how it's pronounced in the original Scandinavian, and Krack-en's closer to that.

question: Well we ain't original Scandinavians, are we? Kray-ken!
answer: It's a mythological creature, I can calls it what I wants.

question: Guard the boat, mind the tide... Don't touch my dirt.
answer: This doesn't work. And it *certainly* doesn't show you what you want most.

question: Yes it *does*. You're sitting on it!
answer: Beg your pardon?

question: How did you get here?
answer: Sea turtles, mate. A pair of them, strapped to my feet.

question: Not so easy, is it?
answer: But I do owe you thanks, Jack.

question: You do?
answer: After you tricked me onto that ship to square your debt with Jones.

question: I can't let you do that, either. So sorry.
answer: I knew you'd warm up to me eventually.

question: Lord Beckett desires the contents of that chest. I deliver it, and get my life back.
answer: Ah. The dark side of ambition.

question: How'd this go all screwy?
answer: Well, each wants the chest for hisself, don't 'e? Mister Norrington, I think he's tryna regain a bit of honor. Old Jack's lookin' to trade it, save his own skin. And Turner there - I figure 'e's tryna... settle some unresolved business 'twixt him and his twice-cursed pirate father.

question: Sad. That chest must be worth more 'n a shiny penny.
answer: Oh! Tsk-tsk-tsk. Terrible temptation.

question: Aye, and we've got her!
answer: We're the faster?

question: Against the wind the Dutchman beats us. That's how she takes her prey. But *with* the wind...
answer: We rob her advantage.

question: No. It's not a reef! Get away from the rail!
answer: What is it?

question: The Kraken. To arms! ?It'll ?attack the starboard. I've seen it before. ?Break out the cannons and hold for my signal. Easy, boys!
answer: Will?

question: Steady! Steady.
answer: Will?

question: *Will?*
answer: *Fire...*! It'll be back. We have to get off the ship.

question: There's no boats.
answer: Pull the grates! Get all the gunpowder onto the net in the cargo hold. Whatever you do, don't miss.
